citances.sentence: The Tribunal is of the view that it is able to consider the results of an IELTS test undertaken after the application was lodged. This view is supported by comments made obiter dicta by Jagot J in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 who indicated that a test undertaken after the application would meet the requirements in cl.485.222, and that it does not have to be the same test as that with respect to which arrangements had been made to meet the requirements of cl.485.215(c).

In MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (21 September 2009) the applicant had provided with the visa application an IELTS test report form showing test scores that were not sufficiently high to demonstrate competent English. The applicant then supplied the Tribunal with an IELTS test report form from a test undertaken after the visa application was lodged which demonstrated that the applicant had achieved a score of at least 6 in each of the test components. Although the decision turned on the proper meaning of the expression "the applicant has made arrangements to undergo" a language test, Jagot J's judgement contains the following obiter observations on the question whether the provisions require the result of 'competent English' for the purpose of cl.485.222 to be the result of the same test in respect of which the applicant had made arrangements to undergo for the purpose of paragraph 485.215(c) (at [38]):
... I see no reason to read the provisions as necessarily requiring the result of competent English for the purpose of cl 485.222 to be the result of the same test in respect of which the applicant had made an arrangement for the purpose of cl 485.215(c). This makes sense. A test may be cancelled for reasons beyond an applicant's control. An applicant may not be able to sit the test arranged for reasons beyond his or her control. ...

The Tribunal also notes that the IELTS test in which the applicant achieved a test score of at least 6 for each of the 4 test components of speaking, reading, writing and listening was not the test in respect of which he had made arrangements to undergo for the purpose of paragraph 485.215(c). In MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (21 September 2009) the applicant had provided with the visa application an IELTS test report form showing test scores that were not sufficiently high to demonstrate competent English. The applicant then supplied the Tribunal with an IELTS test report form from a test undertaken after the visa application was lodged which demonstrated that the applicant had achieved a score of at least 6 in each of the test components. This makes sense. A test may be cancelled for reasons beyond an applicant's control. An applicant may not be able to sit the test arranged for reasons beyond his or her control. ...

The IELTS test which demonstrates that an applicant has achieved sufficient scores to meet the criterion in cl.485.222 does not have to be the same English test for which arrangements had been made at time of application: MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (" Grant ").

The IELTS booking receipt provided by the applicant at time of application was for a test to be undertaken on 17 January 2009. The test undertaken by the applicant on 11 September 2010 is not the test for which the applicant provided the IELTS booking receipt. However, in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , the Court found that the test which an applicant undertook for the purposes of cl.485.222 does not have to be the same test for which the IELTS booking was made.

The IELTS booking receipt provided by the applicant at time of application was for a test to be undertaken on 27 September 2008. The test undertaken by the applicant on 25 September 2010 is not the test for which the applicant provided the IELTS booking receipt. However, in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , the Court found that the test which an applicant undertook for the purposes of cl.485.222 does not have to be the same test for which the IELTS booking was made.

In reaching the decision to refuse the visa, the delegate was satisfied that the applicant had made arrangements to undertake an IELTS test on 29 March 2008 and as this test took place prior to the date of lodgement, the delegate was satisfied that the applicant met the requirements of cl.485.215(c). However, the Tribunal does not accept that the applicant met cl.485.215(c). In order to meet cl.485.215(c), the test must occur after the date of application: MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059. Evidence that the applicant has undergone a test prior to the date of application will not be sufficient to meet the requirements of cl.485.215(c).

The IELTS booking receipt provided by the applicant at time of application was for a test to be undertaken in September or October 2008 The test undertaken by the applicant on 10 April 2010 is not the test for which the applicant provided the IELTS booking receipt. However, in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , the Court found that the test which an applicant undertook for the purposes of cl.485.222 does not have to be the same test for which the IELTS booking was made.

The Tribunal accepts that the applicant has achieved a score of at least 6 in each of the 4 test components in an IELTS test on 26 September 2009. As the IELTS booking receipt was for a test to be undertaken on 6 September 2008, the test undertaken by the applicant on 26 September 2009 is not the test for which the applicant provided the IELTS booking receipt. However, in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , the Court found that the test which an applicant undertook for the purposes of cl.485.222 does not have to be the same test for which the IELTS booking was made. The Tribunal finds, therefore, that the applicant has 'competent English' and that she satisfies cl.485.222(b) and cl.485.222 of Schedule 2.

On 15 April 2010 the Tribunal received submissions from the applicants' newly appointed migration agent, Visa Immigration Specialists Australia Pty Ltd, referring to the recent judgment of Berenguel v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2010] HCA8 of 5 March 2010 (hereinafter referred to as Berenguel ), and submitting that the Tribunal should take into account the IELTS test results provided in March 2010, and that the applicant "must" be found to satisfy the "competent English" requirement. The migration agent further submitted that the reasoning in Berenguel must be taken to have overturned the ratio in Grant v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1059. The agent submitted that a decision could therefore be made on the papers in favour of the applicant (sic).

The applicant has provided the results of an IELTS test which he undertook on 24 August 2010 showing the requisite scores to demonstrate competent English. The Tribunal has verified these results and accordingly is satisfied that the applicant achieved a test score of at least 6 in each of the four test components in a test conducted not more than 2 years before the day on which the application was lodged. The Tribunal notes that this test was undertaken after the test for which evidence of arrangements was provided at the time of application. The Tribunal considers that there is nothing in the Schedule 2 time of decision criterion that requires the language test for which the applicant made arrangements to undergo at the time of application to be the same test at which the applicant succeeded in obtaining the required English standard. This view is supported in a recent decision of MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [38] .

The applicant has provided the results of an IELTS test which he undertook on 10 July 2010 The test results revealed that the applicant achieved the following results: Listening 7.5; Reading 6.0; Writing 6.0 and Speaking 6.0 with an overall band score of 6.5. Therefore the Tribunal is satisfied that the applicant achieved a test score of at least 6 in each of the four test components in a test conducted not more than 2 years before the day on which the application was lodged. The Tribunal notes that this test was undertaken after the test for which evidence of arrangements was provided at the time of application. The Tribunal considers that there is nothing in the Schedule 2 time of decision criterion that requires the language test for which the applicant made arrangements to undergo at the time of application to be the same test at which the applicant succeeded in obtaining the required English standard. This view is supported in a recent decision of MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [38] .

Mr Horan referred to the judgment in Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant & Ors [2009] FCA 1059 and stated that "the issues for decision were slightly different" (T p.24, l.9). The main point there involved the construction of 485.215(c) in circumstances where an applicant failed a language test, but later set another test and satisfied the competent English standard. Mr Horan referred to a "non-Berenguel construction of 485.215(b), because if Berenguel had applied, then it would have been possible to satisfy (b) on the facts of Grant" (T p.31, l.46). That in effect is saying that a single judge of the Federal Court, on hearing an appeal, came to a different conclusion on 485.215(b) than the High Court on 885.213(b). With respect, the decision in Grant does not affect the force of the reasoning in Berenguel.

The applicant has provided the results of an IELTS test which he undertook on 10 July 2010 showing the requisite scores to demonstrate competent English. The Tribunal has verified these results and accordingly is satisfied that the applicant achieved a test score of at least 6 in each of the four test components in a test conducted not more than 2 years before the day on which the application was lodged. The Tribunal notes that this test was undertaken after the test for which evidence of arrangements was provided at the time of application. The Tribunal considers that there is nothing in the Schedule 2 time of decision criterion that requires the language test for which the applicant made arrangements to undergo at the time of application to be the same test at which the applicant succeeded in obtaining the required English standard. This view is supported in a recent decision of MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [38] .

In its decision, the Tribunal refers to the recent decision of Minister for Immigration & Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 which considers the meaning of the phrase " has made arrangements to undergo ". This case concerned the refusal of a Skilled (Provisional) (Class VC) visa. The Court considered the meaning of the words "has made arrangements to undergo" in clause 485.215(c) which states: " the application is accompanied by evidence that the applicant has made arrangements to undergo a language test specified by the Minister in an instrument in writing for this paragraph ".

The applicant has since provided evidence that he undertook an IELTS test on 27 June 2009 in which he achieved the following results: Listening 7.0, Reading 6.0, Writing 6.0, Speaking 6.5. The Tribunal also finds that the applicant has achieved a score of at least 6 in each of the 4 test components on an IELTS test conducted not more than 2 years before the date of application. The Department has verified the IELTS test results. The Tribunal notes that the IELTS test was conducted on 27 June 2009 and therefore relates to a different test than that for which the booking referred. The Tribunal has given consideration to the judgement of the Jagot J. in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 and the Tribunal considers that there is nothing in the Schedule 2 criteria which requires that the language test for which the applicant made arrangements to undergo at the time of application be the same test in which the applicant succeeds in obtaining the required English standard. Accordingly, the Tribunal finds that the applicant has 'competent English' as defined in 1.15C(a)(i). The Tribunal therefore finds that at the time of decision the applicant has competent English and he therefore meets the requirements of cl.485.222.

The Tribunal notes that this test was undertaken after the tests in respect of which evidence of booking arrangements was provided. However, the Tribunal considers that there is nothing in the Schedule 2 time of decision criterion that requires the language test for which an applicant has made arrangements to undergo at the time of application to be the same test in which an applicant succeeds in obtaining the required English standard. (See MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059).

However, the Tribunal considers that there is nothing in the Schedule 2 time of decision criterion that requires the language test for which an applicant has made arrangements to undergo at the time of application to be the same test in which an applicant succeeds in obtaining the required English standard. (See MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059).

The Tribunal notes this test was undertaken after the test for which evidence of arrangements was provided. However, the Tribunal considers that there is nothing in the Schedule 2 time of decision criterion that requires the language test for which an applicant made arrangements to undergo at time of application to be the same test which an applicant succeeds in obtaining the required English standard. (See MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059)

The Tribunal observes that the recent decision of the Federal Court in Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (21 September 2009) draws a specific distinction between those cases where an IELTS test accompanied the visa application and those where this is not the case. In Grant's case , the applicant had provided IELTS test results with his visa application, indicating test scores that were not sufficiently high to demonstrate competent English. The applicant then supplied the Tribunal with IELTS test results for a test undertaken after the visa application was lodged, which demonstrated that he had achieved a score of at least 6 in each of the test components. Her Honour Jagot J held that, in circumstances where an applicant has already taken the language test, but had not achieved the required IELTS test results to meet the definition of competent English, there is no arrangement to undergo anything in the future, as the arrangements for a language test had already been completed.
The Tribunal also enclosed a copy of the Federal Court decision of MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059.

The applicant's representative made extensive submissions as to why the Tribunal should accept these IELTS test results (Tribunal file, folios 140-147). He referred to various cases, in particular, the Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Kamal [2009] FCAFC 98 ; (2009) 178 FCR 379 ( Kamal ), which concerned a student visa application, and the Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 ( Grant ) which concerned Subclass 485 visa application.

Furthermore, although the applicant had submitted with her visa application a booking receipt dated 30 May 2008 indicating that the applicant had been enrolled to sit an IELTS test on 28 June 2008, which was before the visa application was actually lodged, on 25 July 2008. The Tribunal explained that it was bound to follow the decision of the Federal Court in the case of MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , in which it had been held that in such a situation the requirements of subclause 485.215(c) are not satisfied.

Clause 885.213 also requires an applicant to have vocational or competent English at the time of the application. The use of past tense in that provision, which applies at the time when the application is made, also implies that the test must have been conducted before the application was made and not after the date of the application. This is consistent with the Explanatory Statement in the SLI 2007 No. 257 which relevantly states that r. 1.15B requires the IELTS test to be conducted within the two years before the date of the application. The applicant referred to the reasoning in MIAC v Kamal [2009] FCAFC 98 ; (2009) 178 FCR 379 , however, the Tribunal considers such reasoning to be unhelpful, as the Full Court considered the statutory provision that was substantially different to the one that is relevant in this case (cf MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [43] and Chidemo v Minister for Immigration & Anor [2010] FMCA 19).

Clause 885.213 also requires an applicant to have vocational or competent English at the time of the application. The use of past tense in that provision, which applies at the time when the application is made, also implies that the test must have been conducted before the application was made and not after the date of the application. This is consistent with the Explanatory Statement in the SLI 2007 No. 257 which relevantly states that r. 1.15B requires the IELTS test to be conducted within the two years before the date of the application. The Tribunal considers the reasoning in Kamal to be unhelpful, as the Full Court considered the statutory provision that was substantially different to the one that is relevant in this case (cf MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [43] and Chidemo v Minister for Immigration & Anor [2010] FMCA 19).

In defining the term that 'an applicant has made arrangements to undergo a language test" within the meaning of cl 485.215(c) if an applicant has arranged to take, but has not yet taken, the test, Jagot J noted in the decision of Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 that:
The potential anomaly created by this construction (that an applicant would be better off taking a test after the time of application than before if there was any risk of not obtaining the required result before that time) is answered by the fact that demonstrating the making of the arrangement is not onerous and is largely within an applicant's control.
August 2009 he achieved the required score; a copy of that result is attached. It is submitted that the relevant regulation [485.21.5(c)] is in fact able to be satisfied by Mr. Vurugonda in the circumstances. The Tribunal will be aware that in a recent Federal Court of Appeal case (Minister for Immigration & Citizenship v Grant (2009) FCA 1059 20 September 2009) the provisions of 485.215(c) were canvassed. This was a case by way of appeal by the Minister from a Federal Magistrate's decision; it involved different factual circumstances to that in Mr. Vurugonda's case; the visa applicant in that case was eventually unsuccessful although he was successful before the Federal Magistrate. The factual difference is that in that case the IELTS results were received prior to the making of the visa application and were inadequate.

Clause 885.213 also requires an applicant to have vocational or competent English at the time of the application. The use of past tense in that provision, which applies at the time when the application is made, also implies that the test must have been conducted before the application was made and not after the date of the application. This is consistent with the Explanatory Statement in the SLI 2007 No. 257 which relevantly states that r. 1.15B requires the IELTS test to be conducted within the two years before the date of the application. The Tribunal considers the reasoning in Kamal to be unhelpful, as the Full Court considered the statutory provision that was substantially different to the one that is relevant in this case (cf MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [43] and Chidemo v Minister for Immigration & Anor [2010] FMCA 19).

The wording of the requirement --- that a test must be conducted not more than 2 years before the day on which the application was lodged --- is clear and unambiguous and requires the test to have been conducted within a specified period before the application is made. The past tense in the reference to the test being conducted, at the time of application, also implies that the test must have been conducted before the application was made and not after the date of the application. This is also consistent with the Explanatory Statement in the SLI 2007 No. 257 which relevantly states that r. 1.15C requires the IELTS test to be conducted within the two years before the date of the application. The Tribunal considers the reasoning in Kamal to be unhelpful, as the Full Court considered the statutory provision that was substantially different to the one that is relevant in this case (cf MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [43] and Chidemo v Minister for Immigration & Anor [2010] FMCA 19).

The Tribunal is of the view that it is able to consider the results of a test undertaken after the application. This view is supported in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 which confirms both that the test undertaken after the application would meet the requirements in cl.485.222 and also that it need not be the same test as that with respect to which arrangements had been made for the purpose of cl. 485.215(c). The applicant submitted to the Tribunal further IELTS test results dated 28 January 2009, showing that he had undertaken the English language test again on 17 January 2009 The test results by component were speaking 7.5, reading 6.0, writing 6.5 and listening 6.5. These satisfy the Tribunal that the applicant had achieved the score of at least 6 in each of the four test components. These results have been verified by the Tribunal. Therefore he now meets the requirements for 'competent English' as required by cl.485.222.

On 15 November 2009 the applicant provided the Tribunal with a copy of an IELTS test report form indicating that the applicant had achieved scores of 8.5 for speaking and 7.0 for listening, 9.0 for reading, 7.0 for writing and 8.5 for speaking in a test conducted on 9 May 2009. In Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 Jagot J accepted that cl.485.222 should not be read as referring only to the test which the applicant had made arrangements to undergo at the time of application but rather as permitting an applicant to take multiple language tests in order to achieve the necessary result at time of decision.

As referred to in the Tribunal's s.359A letter and as discussed at the hearing before me, there is nothing in the material before me to suggest that the applicant's visa application was accompanied by evidence that she had made arrangements to undergo a language test as required by cl.485.215(c). As the applicant's representatives conceded, in accordance with the decision of the Federal Court in Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , the fact that the applicant had taken a language test and had obtained the results does not constitute evidence that she had made arrangements to undergo a language test as required by cl.485.215(c). The applicant's representatives conceded that, in accordance with the decision of the Federal Court in Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , the fact that the applicant had made arrangements to undergo the language test on 25 August 2007 (the results of which demonstrated that she did not have 'competent English' at the time of application) did not establish that she had 'made arrangements to undergo a language test' within the meaning of cl.485.215(c). They submitted, however, that the applicant had intended to take the language test in future and that they believed that 'there is an implied term that the applicant shall undergo further tests before the decision is made by the Department or the Tribunal'.

In terms of whether the applicant meets cl.485.215 which, in part, requires that the applicant submit, at the time of application, evidence that they intended to sit an IELTS test, the applicant had this evidence at the time of application, however, the test results did not relate to the booking for the test that was ultimately undertaken by the visa applicant. In this regard, the Tribunal has reference to the decision in Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 in which Jagot J states: ...I see no reason to read the provisions as necessarily requiring the result of competent English for the purpose of cl.485.222 to be the result of the same test in respect of which the applicant had made an arrangement for the purpose of cl.485.215(c). This makes sense. A test may be cancelled for reasons beyond an applicant's control. An applicant may not be able to sit the test arranged for reasons beyond his or her control... The applicant at the time of application and decision by the Department had in fact achieved an IELTS test score of at least 6 for each of the 4 test components of speaking, reading, writing and listening and therefore meets cl.485.222. CONCLUSIONS Given the findings made above, the Tribunal remits the matter with a direction that the applicant meets cl.485.215 of Schedule 2 and cl.485.222 of Schedule 2. DECISION The Tribunal remits the application for a Skilled (Provisional) (Class VC) visa for reconsideration, with the direction that the applicant meets the following criteria for a Subclass 485 (Skilled - Graduate) visa: cl.485.215 of Schedule 2 to the Regulations; and cl.485222 of Schedule 2 to the Regulations.
Rosa Gagliardi Date: 27 January 2010 Member

The Federal Court in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (Jagot J, 21 September 2009) considered the construction of cl.485.215. In light of this decision, the Tribunal notes the following considerations and scenarios: What is required to meet cl.485.215(c)?
A.

The applicant has succeeded in meeting the regulations at the review stage by having achieved competent English, on the basis of the test results before the time of decision by the Tribunal, notwithstanding that competent English may not have been achieved in the actual test to which the booking related. The decision in Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (unreported, 21 September 2009, Jagot J) indicates that this approach is appropriate.

The Tribunal has formed the view that the reasoning in Kamal does not apply in this case because it applies only with respect to the provision with which it was concerned --- schedule 5A --- and it is not readily applicable to other provisions such as those contained in r.1.15C and r.1.15B. Indeed, the Full Court in Kamal noted that 'the complexity of the Regulations and the various occasions upon which they have been amended suggests that comparison of the language of Item 5A404 with the language of other provisions in the Regulations is likely to be of little assistance' (at [18], see also MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [43] ).

These indicate that one of the marks has been increased from 5.5 to 6 and that the applicant had achieved the score of at least 6 in each of the four test components. Prior to the applicant lodging her application, cl.485.222 which has now been removed, enabled an applicant to demonstrate that at the time of application they had made arrangements to sit an IELTS test and the decision in Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (unreported, 21 September 2009, Jagot J) enabled the applicant to succeed at the review stage by having competent English, on the basis of her latest test results, before the time of decision, notwithstanding that competent English had not been achieved in the actual test to which the booking related. With the removal of cl.485.222 on 27 October 2009, this is no longer the case and the visa applicant's application must fail. Ministerial Intervention Considerations

The Tribunal is of the view that it is able to consider the results of an IELTS test undertaken after the application was lodged. This view is supported by comments made obiter dicta by Jagot J in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 who indicated that a test undertaken after the application would meet the requirements in cl.485.222, and that it does not have to be the same test as that with respect to which arrangements had been made to meet the requirements of cl.485.215(c).

The decision in Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (unreported, 21 September 2009, Jagot J) indicates that the applicant could have succeeded if at the time of review he had completed and submitted an IELTS test with a score of at least 6 for each of the test components. As this has not occurred, the application cannot succeed.

The Tribunal finds in relation to the language test that the applicant had already sat in August 2007, that evidence of this is not sufficient to meet cl.485.215(c). To meet cl.485.215(c), the test must occur after the date of application. Evidence that the applicant has undergone a test prior to the date of application will not be sufficient to meet cl.485.215(c): MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (Jagot J, 21 September 2009) The applicant was uncertain at the hearing as to whether, at the date of application, she had in fact made arrangements for language testing (ie for the language test that took place on 6 December 2008, some months after lodgement of the application). --- The submission of 10 December 2009 has attached to it a copy of a handwritten note on plain paper with an invoice number that purports to be an 'IELTS booking receipt' in lieu of an original that was lost. The note records the booking date as 18 October 2008.

The Federal Court in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (Jagot J, 21 September 2009) considered the construction of cl.485.215. In light of this decision, the Tribunal notes the following considerations and scenarios that may be relevant to the present case: (i) What is required to meet cl.485.215(c)?
A. Test results may be regarded as evidence of that level of English, and if the test was undertaken in the 2 years prior to application, it may be said that the applicant has the requisite level of English at the time of application. The fact that the evidence of that standard of English is only available after the application is made does not mean that the applicant did not satisfy the relevant English language requirement at the time of application. An applicant in these circumstances could not meet cl.485.215(c) because to satisfy that paragraph the test must not have been taken at the time of application: MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [42] . (vi) Can the applicant meet cl.485.215(c), if
- s/he undertakes a test in the 2 years prior to the application and fails to achieve the requisite test score, but
- provides evidence with the application that s/he has made arrangements to undertake another IELTS or OELT test after the date application?
Yes.
Yes. Clause 485.215(c) is an alternative to paragraphs (a) and (b), and is not expressed as being conditional upon the applicant not having undertaken a test in the preceding 2 years. Justice Jagot in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 did observe that it was not the purpose of the scheme to encourage an applicant to take multiple tests, but her Honour did not specifically address this scenario, or conclude that cl.485.215(c) could only be met by persons who had not previously sat a test. (vii) Can the applicant meet cl.485.215(a) or (b) if s/he achieves the requisite score in a test undertaken after the date of application?
A.

At the date of application, the applicant had evidence of a language test booking, but Mr Kugan had told him that it was not necessary to provide test bookings, only the results. Under cover of a submission dated 22 December 2009 the applicant's representatives provided the Tribunal with a copy of an IELTS test report form indicating that the applicant had achieved scores of 7.0 for listening, 7.0 for reading, 6.0 for writing and 6.5 for speaking in a test conducted on 30 May 2009. As the applicant's representatives noted, in Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 Jagot J accepted that cl.485.222 should not be read as referring only to the test which the applicant had made arrangements to undergo at the time of application but rather as permitting an applicant to take multiple language tests in order to achieve the necessary result at time of decision.

A test undertaken before the application is made cannot constitute evidence of arrangements to undergo a language test. As the Federal Court held in the case of MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , at [31]:
An arrangement to undergo something involves a thing yet to be done. An element of futurity is involved. Meaning 1 involves no element of futurity.

The Tribunal observes that the recent decision of the Federal Court in Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (21 September 2009) draws a specific distinction between those cases where an IELTS test accompanied the visa application and those where this is not the case. In Grant's case , the applicant had provided IELTS test results with his visa application, indicating test scores that were not sufficiently high to demonstrate competent English. The applicant then supplied the Tribunal with IELTS test results for a test undertaken after the visa application was lodged, which demonstrated that he had achieved a score of at least 6 in each of the test components. Her Honour Jagot J held that, in circumstances where an applicant has already taken the language test, but had not achieved the required IELTS test results to meet the definition of competent English, there is no arrangement to undergo anything in the future, as the arrangements for a language test had already been completed.

The visa applicant stated that he was aware that a number of his representatives other clients had succeeded in their subclass 485 visa applications before the Tribunal and had been allowed to undertake a further IELTS test and provide the results to the Tribunal; he stated that he was unsure as to why this was not applicable in his case. The Tribunal explained that the issue in his case related to a time of application criterion and it was likely that the cases he was referring to had involved a time of decision criterion. In particular, the Tribunal clarified for the visa applicant how the decision in Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (21 September 2009) applied to his case, given that evidence of an IELTS test booking had not accompanied his visa application in May 2008. Mr Savneet Dhillon, the visa applicant's brother, queried whether the judgment in Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 would apply to the visa applicant, given In respect of the IELTS test results achieved by the visa applicant on 20 November 2008, the Tribunal notes that the recent decision of the Federal Court in Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (21 September 2009) applies. In Grant's case , the applicant had provided IELTS test results with his visa application, indicating test scores that were not sufficiently high to demonstrate competent English. The applicant then supplied the Tribunal with IELTS test results for a test undertaken after the visa application was lodged, which demonstrated that he had achieved a score of at least 6.0 in each of the test components. Her Honour Jagot J held that, in circumstances where an applicant has already taken the language test, but had not achieved the required IELTS test results to meet the definition of competent English, there is no arrangement to undergo anything in the future, as the arrangements for a language test had already been completed. Accordingly, the Court held that the fact that an applicant subsequently proves that he/she has competent English by the taking of a test at a later date is insufficient to satisfy the requirements of paragraph 485.215(c).

In respect of the IELTS test the visa applicant proposes to undertake on 9 January 2010 and, in the event that the visa applicant achieves results in that test that indicate she possesses competent English, the Tribunal notes that the recent decision of the Federal Court in Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (21 September 2009) applies. In Grant's case , the applicant had provided IELTS test results with his visa application, indicating test scores that were not sufficiently high to demonstrate competent English. The applicant then supplied the Tribunal with IELTS test results for a test undertaken after the visa application was lodged, which demonstrated that he had achieved a score of at least 6 in each of the test components. Her Honour Jagot J held that, in circumstances where an applicant has already taken the language test, but had not achieved the required IELTS test results to meet the definition of competent English, there is no arrangement to undergo anything in the future, as the arrangements for a language test had already been completed. Accordingly, the Court held that the fact that an applicant subsequently proves that he/she has competent English by the taking of a test at a later date is insufficient to satisfy the requirements of paragraph 485.215(c).

In the recent decision of the Federal Court in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (21 September 2009) the applicant had provided with the visa application an IELTS test report form showing test scores that were not sufficiently high to demonstrate competent English. Although the decision turned on the proper meaning of the expression "the applicant has made arrangements to undergo" a language test, Jagot J's judgement contains the following obiter observations on the question of whether the provisions require the result of 'competent English' for the purpose of clause 485.222 to be the result of the same test in respect of which the applicant had made arrangements to undergo for the purpose of paragraph 485.215(c) (at [38]):
... This makes sense. A test may be cancelled for reasons beyond an applicant's control. An applicant may not be able to sit the test arranged for reasons beyond his or her control. ...

The Federal Court in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (Jagot J, 21 September 2009) considered the construction of cl.485.215. In light of this decision, the Tribunal notes the following considerations and scenarios: What is required to meet cl.485.215(c)?
A.

In the Tribunal's opinion, it is clear that evidence of "arrangements to undergo" involves an element of futurity. As Jagot J noted in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [31] , "[A]n arrangement to undergo something involves a thing yet to be done. " His Honour further noted [at 28] that: First, the arrangements must have been made, in the sense of being in place or in existence, when the application is made. Second, the arrangements must be to undergo, in the sense of to take or to sit for, a test.

The Federal Court in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (Jagot J, 21 September 2009) considered the construction of cl.485.215. In light of this decision, the Tribunal notes the following considerations and scenarios: What is required to meet cl.485.215(c)?
A.
Yes. Clause 485.215(c) is an alternative to paragraphs (a) and (b), and is not expressed as being conditional upon the applicant not haven undertaken a test in the preceding 2 years. Justice Jagot in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 did observe that it was not the purpose of the scheme to encourage an applicant to take multiple tests, but her Honour did not specifically address this scenario, or conclude that cl.485.215(c) could only be met by persons who had not previously sat a test.

As the applicant has not met cl.485.215(1) or (b), the Tribunal has considered whether the applicant meets cl.485.215(c). There is nothing before the Tribunal to indicate that the application was accompanied by evidence of arrangements to undergo a test and the applicant confirmed in his oral evidence to the Tribunal that his application was not accompanied by evidence of arrangements to undergo a test because he was not aware of this requirement and because his migration agent failed to inform him that he had to repeat the IELTS test. While the applicant did undertake an IELTS test before the application was lodged, such a test does not meet the requirements of cl. 485.215(c) because this provision refers to a future test and not a test that the applicant had already undertaken. Such a test is not sufficient to meet the requirements in cl.485.215(c) because at the time of the application, there were no longer any arrangements to undergo a test (see MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059).

In MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , Jagot J (sitting as the Full Federal Court) found:
37. ... By this I mean that cll 485. [2]15 and 485.222, read together and in the light of ss 31(3) and 65 of the Migration Act and reg 2.03(1) of the Migration Regulations , disclose that the legislature intended to give an applicant two opportunities to demonstrate competent English. An applicant who had taken a test and obtained the results could demonstrate competent English at the time of the application (cl 485.215(b)). An applicant who had made an arrangement to take a test may demonstrate competent English at the time of decision (cc 485.215(c) and 485.222(b)). ...

In MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , Jagot J (sitting as the Full Federal Court) found:
37. ... By this I mean that cll 485. [2]15 and 485.222, read together and in the light of ss 31(3) and 65 of the Migration Act and reg 2.03(1) of the Migration Regulations , disclose that the legislature intended to give an applicant two opportunities to demonstrate competent English. An applicant who had taken a test and obtained the results could demonstrate competent English at the time of the application (cl 485.215(b)). An applicant who had made an arrangement to take a test may demonstrate competent English at the time of decision (cc 485.215(c) and 485.222(b)). ...

As the applicant has not met cl.485.215(1) or (b), the Tribunal has considered whether the applicant meets cl.485.215(c). There is nothing before the Tribunal to indicate that the application was accompanied by evidence of arrangements to undergo a test. The applicant argues that she had done the IELTS test before the application but due to illness, she did not achieve the requisite score. However, as the Federal Court stated in M IAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059:
an arrangement to undergo something involves an element of futurity, in the sense of a thing yet to be done. Where a visa applicant has made an arrangement for an IELTS test and has already undertaken the test, there is no longer an arrangement to undergo anything in the future and cannot satisfy cl.485.215(c).

The applicant argues that the reasoning in Kamal applies in this case. However, the Tribunal is of the view that the reasoning in Kamal applies only with respect to the provision with which it was concerned --- schedule 5A --- and it is not readily applicable to other provisions such as those contained in r. 1.15C (see also MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [43] ). While the High Court may take a different view in Berenguel , the Tribunal is of the view that a more narrow approach to the wording in r. 1.15C is justified, so that the language test must be done before the application and cannot be done after the application. The Tribunal does not consider this interpretation to be inconsistent with the purpose of the legislation, having regard to the explanatory memorandum.

The Federal Court in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (Jagot J, 21 September 2009) considered the construction of cl.485.215. In light of this decision, the Tribunal notes the following considerations and scenarios: What is required to meet cl.485.215(c)?
A. The language test she undertook on 30 August 2008 cannot satisfy cl.485.215(c) because to satisfy that paragraph the test must not have been taken at the time of application: MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [42] .

The applicant's representative submitted that the case of MIAC -v- Grant (2009) FCA 1059 does not make it clear what the time line is for evidence accompanying the application. He also submitted that the applicant has now provided evidence that he has 'competent English. ' The Tribunal does not accept the submission in relation to Grant's case In the case of Grant the Court stated at paragraph 26: "It is apparent from the structure of cll.485.21 and 485.22 of Sch 2 to the Migration Regulations that they are dealing, respectively, with requirements that must be satisfied at the time of making and deciding an application for the relevant subclass of visa. .....The requirements are substantive in the sense that, if not satisfied, the Minister (and thus the Tribunal) is bound to refuse the grant of a visa. "(Emphasis added). (MIAC -v- Grant (2009) FCA 1059). The applicant's representative submitted that the case of MIAC -v- Grant (2009) FCA 1059 does not make it clear what the time line is for evidence accompanying the application. He also submitted that the applicant has now provided evidence that he has 'competent English. ' The Tribunal does not accept the submission in relation to Grant's case In the case of Grant the Court stated at paragraph 26: "It is apparent from the structure of cll.485.21 and 485.22 of Sch 2 to the Migration Regulations that they are dealing, respectively, with requirements that must be satisfied at the time of making and deciding an application for the relevant subclass of visa. .....The requirements are substantive in the sense that, if not satisfied, the Minister (and thus the Tribunal) is bound to refuse the grant of a visa. "(Emphasis added). (MIAC -v- Grant (2009) FCA 1059).

The Tribunal has found nothing in the material before it to evidence that the visa application was accompanied by evidence the applicant had made arrangements to undergo a language test as required by cl.485.215(c). The applicant undertook an IELTS test on 19 January 2008 and was awaiting the result when she made her visa application. However, this evidence does not meet cl.485.215(c) because to satisfy that paragraph the test must not have been taken at the time of application: MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [42] . The Federal Court in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (Jagot J, 21 September 2009) considered the construction of cl.485.215. In light of this decision, the Tribunal notes the following considerations and scenarios: What is required to meet cl.485.215(c)?
A.
Yes. Clause 485.215(c) is an alternative to paragraphs (a) and (b), and is not expressed as being conditional upon the applicant not haven undertaken a test in the preceding 2 years. Justice Jagot in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 did observe that it was not the purpose of the scheme to encourage an applicant to take multiple tests, but her Honour did not specifically address this scenario, or conclude that cl.485.215(c) could only be met by persons who had not previously sat a test. Can the applicant meet cl.485.215(a) or (b) if s/he achieves the requisite score in a test undertaken after the date of application?
A. Test results may be regarded as evidence of that level of English, and if the test was undertaken in the 2 years prior to application, it may be said that the applicant has the requisite level of English at the time of application. The fact that the evidence of that standard of English is only available after the application is made does not mean that the applicant did not satisfy the relevant English language requirement at the time of application. An applicant in these circumstances could not meet cl.485.215(c) because to satisfy that paragraph the test must not have been taken at the time of application: MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [42] . Can the applicant meet cl.485.215(c), if
- s/he undertakes a test in the 2 years prior the application and fails to achieves the requisite test score, but
- provides evidence with the application that s/he has made arrangements to undertake another IELTS or OELT test after the date application?
Yes.

Another difficulty with the applicant's submission is the definition of 'competent English' in r. 1.15C, which expressly refers to the test being undertaken "not more than 2 years before the day on which the application was lodged". The Explanatory Statement to SLI 2007 No. 257, to which the applicant referred, equally suggests that the language test must have been conducted within 2 years before the date of the application. The applicant correctly points out that there is no proscription of the test being undertaken after the application and that was the reasoning put forward in Kamal . However, the Tribunal is of the view that the reasoning in Kamal applies only with respect to the provision with which it was concerned --- schedule 5A --- and it is not readily applicable to other provisions such as those contained in r. 1.15C (see also MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [43] ). While the High Court may take a different view in Berenguel , the Tribunal is of the view that a more narrow approach to the wording in r. 1.15C is justified, so that the language test must be done before the application and cannot be done after the application. The Tribunal does not consider this interpretation to be inconsistent with the purpose of the legislation, having regard to the explanatory memorandum

The applicant provided to the Tribunal an IELTS test result for a test undertaken on 8 March 2008 where the results were released after the date of the application. However, evidence that the applicant has undergone a test prior to the date of application is not sufficient to meet cl.485.215(c) because to satisfy that paragraph the test must not have been taken at the time of application: MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [42] . - s/he undertakes a test in the 2 years prior the application and fails to achieves the requisite test score, but
- provides evidence with the application that s/he has made arrangements to undertake another IELTS or OELT test after the date application?

A. Justice Jagot in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 did observe that it was not the purpose of the scheme to encourage an applicant to take multiple tests, but her Honour did not specifically address this scenario, or conclude that cl.485.215(c) could only be met by persons who had not previously sat a test. In the recent decision of the Federal Court in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (21 September 2009) the applicant had provided with the visa application an IELTS test report form showing test scores that were not sufficiently high to demonstrate competent English. The applicant then supplied the Tribunal with an IELTS test report form from a test undertaken after the visa application was lodged which demonstrated that the applicant had achieved a score of at least 6 in each of the test components. Although the decision turned on the proper meaning of the expression "the applicant has made arrangements to undergo" a language test, Jagot J's judgement contains the following obiter observations on the question whether the provisions require the result of 'competent English' for the purpose of clause 485.222 to be the result of the same test in respect of which the applicant had made arrangements to undergo for the purpose of paragraph 485.215(c) (at [38]):
... I see no reason to read the provisions as necessarily requiring the result of competent English for the purpose of cl 485.222 to be the result of the same test in respect of which the applicant had made an arrangement for the purpose of cl 485.215(c). This makes sense. A test may be cancelled for reasons beyond an applicant's control. An applicant may not be able to sit the test arranged for reasons beyond his or her control. ...

The Federal Court in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (Jagot J, 21 September 2009) considered the construction of cl.485.215. In light of this decision, the Tribunal notes the following considerations and scenarios: What is required to meet cl.485.215(c)?
A.

The Federal Court in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (Jagot J, 21 September 2009) considered the construction of cl.485.215. In light of this decision, the Tribunal notes the following considerations and scenarios: What is required to meet cl.485.215(c)?
A.

The Tribunal notes that the Department's decision states that the visa applicant had "applied for an IELTS test on 12/04/08" when in fact he had applied to undertake that test on 14 January 2008. Regardless, it is evident to the Tribunal that at the time of application on 20 February 2008, the applicant had made arrangements to undertake an IELTS test. The applicant has succeeded in meeting the regulations at the review stage by having achieved competent English, on the basis of his latest test results, before the time of decision, notwithstanding that competent English may not have been achieved in the actual test to which the booking related. The decision in Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (unreported, 21 September 2009, Jagot J) indicates that this approach is appropriate.

The Tribunal notes that the applicant had undertaken an initial IELTS test on 19 April 2008 as she intended. When the Department was making its decision, however, the applicant had not achieved at least 6 for each of the 4 test components and the applicant was therefore deemed not to have Competent English as specified in Migration Regulation 1.15C. Prior to the Tribunal making its decision, however, the visa applicant undertook a further test on 12 September 2009, in which she was successful in achieving at least 6 for each of the 4 test components. The applicant has thus succeeded in meeting the regulations at the review stage by having achieved competent English, on the basis of the test results before the time of decision by the Tribunal, notwithstanding that competent English may not have been achieved in the actual test to which the booking related. The decision in Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (unreported, 21 September 2009, Jagot J) indicates that this approach is appropriate

For the reasons set out in the Tribunal's decision 071956137 [2008] MRTA 1109 , the Tribunal is of the view that it is able to consider the results of a test undertaken after the application. This view is supported in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 which confirms both that the test undertaken after the application would meet the requirements in cl. 485.222 and also that it need not be the same test as that with respect to which arrangements had been made for the purpose of cl. 485.215(c).

The applicant's agent drew attention to Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (21 September 2009) and to two decisions recently made by Tribunal members where the situation was that 'even if the [IELTS] test was not conducted before the date [of application], the visa may still be granted'. The applicant's migration agent drew attention to the recent decision of the Federal Court in Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (21 September 2009). In Grant's case, the applicant had provided IELTS test results with his visa application, indicating test scores that were not sufficiently high to demonstrate competent English. The applicant then supplied the Tribunal with IELTS test results for a test undertaken after the visa application was lodged, which demonstrated that he had achieved a score of at least 6 in each of the test components. His Honour Jagot J held that, in circumstances where an applicant has already taken the language test, but had not achieved the required IELTS test results to meet the definition of competent English, there is no arrangement to undergo anything in the future, as the arrangements for a language test had already been completed. Accordingly, the Court held that the fact that an applicant subsequently proves that he/she has competent English by the taking of a test at a later date is insufficient to satisfy the requirements of paragraph 485.215(c).

The applicant has provided the results of an IELTS test which she undertook on 8 August 2009 showing the requisite scores to demonstrate vocational English. The Tribunal has verified these results and accordingly is satisfied that the applicant achieved a test score of at least 5 in each of the 4 test components in a test conducted not more than 2 years before the day on which the application was lodged. The Tribunal notes that this test was undertaken after the test for which evidence of arrangements was provided at the time of application. The Tribunal considers that there is nothing in the Schedule 2 time of decision criterion that requires the language test for which the applicant made arrangements to undergo at the time of application to be the same test at which the applicant succeeded in obtaining the required English standard. This view is supported in a recent decision of MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [38] .

The Tribunal does accept that the applicant has been caught out by what might be called a matter of form rather than substance. In substance, he had made his booking. He merely (or, more correctly, his agent) did not submit evidence of it along with his application. Had he done so, it seems to the Tribunal that the applicant could have succeeded at the review stage by having achieved competent English, on the basis of his latest test results, before the time of decision, notwithstanding that competent English was not achieved in the actual test to which the booking related. This appears to be what is suggested in Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (unreported, 21 September 2009, Jagot J).

The applicant has provided the results of an IELTS test which he undertook on 22 August 2009 showing the requisite scores to demonstrate competent English. The Tribunal has verified these results and accordingly is satisfied that the applicant achieved a test score of at least 6 in each of the four test components in a test conducted not more than 2 years before the day on which the application was lodged. The Tribunal notes that this test was undertaken after the test for which evidence of arrangements was provided at the time of application. The Tribunal considers that there is nothing in the Schedule 2 time of decision criterion that requires the language test for which the applicant made arrangements to undergo at the time of application to be the same test at which the applicant succeeded in obtaining the required English standard. This view is supported in a recent decision of MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [38] .

The Tribunal notes that the Federal Court has recently considered the meaning of paragraph 485.215(c) in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 ( Grant ). Jagot J held:
46. ... Mr Grant did not satisfy the requirements of cl. 485.215(c) of the Migration Regulations . At the time of the application for the visa, he had not "made arrangements to undergo a language test specified by the Minister in an instrument in writing" within the meaning of that provision. ... Hence, the fact that Mr Grant subsequently provided that he had "competent English" by the taking of a test at a later time (and before the Tribunal made its decision) is insufficient; the first requirement had not been met.

The applicant has provided the results of an IELTS test which he undertook on 26 September 2009 showing the requisite scores to demonstrate competent English. The Tribunal has verified these results and accordingly is satisfied that the applicant achieved a test score of at least 6 in each of the four test components in a test conducted not more than 2 years before the day on which the application was lodged. The Tribunal notes that this test was undertaken after the test for which evidence of arrangements was provided at the time of application. The Tribunal considers that there is nothing in the Schedule 2 time of decision criterion that requires the language test for which the applicant made arrangements to undergo at the time of application to be the same test at which the applicant succeeded in obtaining the required English standard. This view is supported in a recent decision of MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [38] .

For the reasons set out in the Tribunal's decision 071956137 [2008] MRTA 1109 , the Tribunal is of the view that it is able to consider the results of a test undertaken after the application This view is supported in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 which confirms both that the test undertaken after the application would meet the requirements in cl. 485.222 and also that it need not be the same test as that with respect to which arrangements had been made for the purpose of cl. 485.215(c).

The Tribunal received submissions from the applicant's representative on 27 October and 12 and 13 November 2009 The submission indicated that the applicant had booked an IELTS test at the time of application, but because of the inadequacy of the on-line visa application form, there was no facility to indicate the booking of a test. The representative submitted that because the applicant had made the booking at the time of application, the requirements of cl.485.215 were met. The representative submitted that the word 'accompany' also means 'co-exist with' or 'exist together' and that as the applicant had booked to undergo an IELTS test, it 'co-existed with the application'. The representative also submitted that the applicant now had competent English on the basis of the results of his IELTS test taken on 17 January 2009. The representative included evidence of a receipt dated 9 January 2008 for an IELTS test on 29 March 2008. The representative included a copy of the decision of MIAC v Grant (2009) FCA 1059 and a number of other Tribunal decisions on this issue.

And finally, she booked a further test on 5 September 2008, as quickly as possible. The Tribunal accepts this chronology, although it does not consider material whether the applicant learned of her unsuccessful test outcome late on 4 September 2008 or the following day. In essence, Mr Guan invited the Tribunal to consider that the word 'arrangements' means any intentions or plans, even contingent; to also take a liberal approach to what might amount to relevant evidence; and to consider the application not as the time of lodgement, but rather the entire application process before a decision is made He suggested that this was consistent with or flowed from the Federal Court's decision in MIAC v Grant [4] , in particular its observation that an arrangement necessarily refers to a future action. The Tribunal understands the Federal Court to have been addressing in Grant the scenario in which an applicant had previously made arrangements for and undergone a language test in the past, and was now seeking to rely on those past arrangements to satisfy the time of application requirement in cl.485.215(c). Mr Guan's interpretation seeks to extend the notion of 'futurity' to an altogether different scenario --- namely to any intention or plan, even contingent. The phrase was considered in MIAC v Grant [2] in the context of cl.485.215(c) though the Federal Court's conclusions are equally applicable to the Subclass 487 time of application criteria which employ this phrase. This judgement made clear that there are a number of scenarios that will not satisfy the requirements to have "made arrangements to undergo a language test". For instance, it addressed the situation where an applicant has arranged and undergone a language test before the making of the application. The Court was clear that in such circumstances the criterion would not be satisfied as this meaning disregarded "the commonsense proposition, demonstrated by the statutory scheme, that an arrangement to undergo a test is only relevant where the results of the test remain unavailable" and that "the natural and ordinary meaning of the phrase denotes a future requirement". [3] Given the findings above, the Tribunal must affirm the decision under review. DECISION
The Tribunal affirms the decision not to grant the applicants Skilled (Provisional) (Class VC) visas
James Silva Member

Mr Guan also discussed the meaning of the term: 'if the application was accompanied by evidence that the applicant has made arrangements to undergo a language test'. The ultimate statutory purpose is to ascertain whether an applicant has "competent English". He suggested that application, particularly in the context of an on-line application, should be taken to mean more than the physical application, but rather the process of applying up to the time of decision.

Time of decision criteria The Tribunal confirmed the applicant's circumstances, and discussed with him and Mr Bhardwaj the operation of cl.485.215 and the Federal Court's recent decision in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059. It handed a copy of the decision to Mr Bhardwaj. Given the findings above, the Tribunal affirms the decision under review. DECISION
The Tribunal affirms the decision not to grant the applicant a Skilled (Provisional) (Class VC) visa. James Silva Member

As the applicant has not met cl.485.215(a) or (b), the Tribunal has considered whether the applicant meets cl.485.215(c). The Tribunal has considered the representative's submission that the applicant meets cl.485.215(c) on the basis of the IELTS test of 3 September 2007 provided to the Department. The Tribunal is not satisfied that this test, undertaken prior to the date of application, is evidence in accordance with cl.485.215(c). The Tribunal considers that such an approach is consistent with the Full Federal Court decision in Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , at [28] to [29]. The Tribunal, therefore, finds that the applicant's visa application was not accompanied by evidence that the applicant had made arrangements to undergo a language test specified for the purposes of cl.485.215(c). Accordingly, the applicant does not satisfy cl.485.215(c).

The applicant has provided the results of an IELTS test which he undertook on 24 October 2009 showing the requisite scores to demonstrate competent English. The Tribunal has verified these results and accordingly is satisfied that the applicant achieved a test score of at least 6 in each of the four test components in a test conducted not more than 2 years before the day on which the application was lodged. The Tribunal notes that this test was undertaken after the test for which evidence of arrangements was provided at the time of application. This view is supported in a recent decision of MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [38] .
