... I see no reason to read the provisions as necessarily requiring the result of competent English for the purpose of cl 485.222 to be the result of the same test in respect of which the applicant had made an arrangement for the purpose of cl 485.215(c). This makes sense. A test may be cancelled for reasons beyond an applicant's control. An applicant may not be able to sit the test arranged for reasons beyond his or her control. ...

In the recent decision of the Federal Court in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (21 September 2009) the applicant had provided with the visa application an IELTS test report form showing test scores that were not sufficiently high to demonstrate competent English. The applicant then supplied the Tribunal with an IELTS test report form from a test undertaken after the visa application was lodged which demonstrated that the applicant had achieved a score of at least 6 in each of the test components. Although the decision turned on the proper meaning of the expression "the applicant has made arrangements to undergo" a language test, Jagot J's judgement contains the following obiter observations on the question whether the provisions require the result of 'competent English' for the purpose of clause 485.222 to be the result of the same test in respect of which the applicant had made arrangements to undergo for the purpose of paragraph 485.215(c) (at [38]):
... I see no reason to read the provisions as necessarily requiring the result of competent English for the purpose of cl 485.222 to be the result of the same test in respect of which the applicant had made an arrangement for the purpose of cl 485.215(c). This makes sense. A test may be cancelled for reasons beyond an applicant's control. An applicant may not be able to sit the test arranged for reasons beyond his or her control. ...

The facts of this case are not dissimilar to those considered by the court in M IAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059. Significantly, the Court emphasised in Grant at [31]:
an arrangement to undergo something involves an element of futurity, in the sense of a thing yet to be done. Where a visa applicant has made an arrangement for an IELTS test and has already undertaken the test, there is no longer an arrangement to undergo anything in the future and cannot satisfy cl.485.215(c).

The meaning of the phrase "has made arrangements to undergo" was considered recently in the case of MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059. This case concerned the refusal of a Skilled (Provisional) (Class VC) visa and the Federal Court of Australia considered the meaning of the words "has made arrangements to undergo" in clause 485.215(c) which states: 'the application is accompanied by evidence that the applicant has made arrangements to undergo a language test specified by the Minister in an instrument in writing for this paragraph. ' Her Honour, Jagot J stated (at para 28): "The purpose of the provision, to enable an applicant to demonstrate competent English at the time of application or of decision, is best achieved by giving the words their ordinary meaning. The ordinary meaning of the phrase 'has made arrangements to undergo' involves two key aspects. First, the arrangements must have been made, in the sense of being in place or in existence, when the application is made. Second, the arrangements must be to undergo, in the sense of to take or to sit for, a test. "

The facts of this case are not dissimilar to those considered by the court in M IAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059. Significantly, the Court emphasised in Grant at [31]:
an arrangement to undergo something involves an element of futurity, in the sense of a thing yet to be done. Where a visa applicant has made an arrangement for an IELTS test and has already undertaken the test, there is no longer an arrangement to undergo anything in the future and cannot satisfy cl.485.215(c).

Mr Guan made a rather wide-ranging oral submission. Essentially, he contended that the Tribunal should accept that the application was accompanied by evidence of the applicant having made arrangements to undergo a language test, in light of the following: He referred the Tribunal to the Federal Court decision in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , in which Jagot J found in relation to cl.485.215(c): -
In this context the words "the application is accompanied by evidence that the applicant has made arrangements to undergo a language test" are directed towards an outcome contemplated by cl 485.222, being proof that an applicant has "competent English" The purpose of the provision, to enable an applicant to demonstrate competent English at the time of application or of decision, is best achieved by giving the words their ordinary meaning. The ordinary meaning of the phrase "has made arrangements to undergo" involves two key aspects. First, the arrangements must have been made, in the sense of being in place or in existence, when the application is made.

In the recent decision of the Federal Court in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (21 September 2009) the applicant had provided with the visa application an IELTS test report form showing test scores that were not sufficiently high to demonstrate competent English. The applicant then supplied the Tribunal with an IELTS test report form from a test undertaken after the visa application was lodged which demonstrated that the applicant had achieved a score of at least 6 in each of the test components. Although the decision turned on the proper meaning of the expression "the applicant has made arrangements to undergo" a language test, Jagot J's judgement contains the following obiter observations on the question whether the provisions require the result of 'competent English' for the purpose of clause 485.222 to be the result of the same test in respect of which the applicant had made arrangements to undergo for the purpose of paragraph 485.215(c) (at [38]):
... I see no reason to read the provisions as necessarily requiring the result of competent English for the purpose of cl 485.222 to be the result of the same test in respect of which the applicant had made an arrangement for the purpose of cl 485.215(c). This makes sense. A test may be cancelled for reasons beyond an applicant's control. An applicant may not be able to sit the test arranged for reasons beyond his or her control. ...

On 3 November 2009 the applicant provided the Tribunal with a copy of an IELTS test report form indicating that the applicant had achieved scores of 8.0 for listening,7.0 for reading, 7.0 for writing and 7.5 for speaking in a test conducted on 8 October 2009. As highlighted in the applicant's submission, in Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 Jagot J accepted that cl.485.222 should not be read as referring only to the test which the applicant had made arrangements to undergo at the time of application but rather as permitting an applicant to take multiple language tests in order to achieve the necessary result at time of decision.

In the recent decision of the Federal Court in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (21 September 2009) the applicant had provided with the visa application an IELTS test report form showing test scores that were not sufficiently high to demonstrate competent English. The applicant then supplied the Tribunal with an IELTS test report form from a test undertaken after the visa application was lodged which demonstrated that the applicant had achieved a score of at least 6 in each of the test components. Although the decision turned on the proper meaning of the expression "the applicant has made arrangements to undergo" a language test, Jagot J's judgement contains the following obiter observations on the question whether the provisions require the result of 'competent English' for the purpose of clause 485.222 to be the result of the same test in respect of which the applicant had made arrangements to undergo for the purpose of paragraph 485.215(c) (at [38]):
... I see no reason to read the provisions as necessarily requiring the result of competent English for the purpose of cl 485.222 to be the result of the same test in respect of which the applicant had made an arrangement for the purpose of cl 485.215(c). This makes sense. A test may be cancelled for reasons beyond an applicant's control. An applicant may not be able to sit the test arranged for reasons beyond his or her control. ...

In the recent decision of the Federal Court in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 (21 September 2009) the applicant had provided with the visa application an IELTS test report form showing test scores that were not sufficiently high to demonstrate competent English. The applicant then supplied the Tribunal with an IELTS test report form from a test undertaken after the visa application was lodged which demonstrated that the applicant had achieved a score of at least 6 in each of the test components. Although the decision turned on the proper meaning of the expression "the applicant has made arrangements to undergo" a language test, Jagot J's judgement contains the following obiter observations on the question whether the provisions require the result of 'competent English' for the purpose of clause 485.222 to be the result of the same test in respect of which the applicant had made arrangements to undergo for the purpose of paragraph 485.215(c) (at [38]):
... I see no reason to read the provisions as necessarily requiring the result of competent English for the purpose of cl 485.222 to be the result of the same test in respect of which the applicant had made an arrangement for the purpose of cl 485.215(c). This makes sense. A test may be cancelled for reasons beyond an applicant's control. An applicant may not be able to sit the test arranged for reasons beyond his or her control. ...

For the reasons set out in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , the Tribunal is of the view that it is able to consider the results of a test undertaken after the application and further that the test undertaken after the application would meet the requirements in cl. 485.222 and also that it need not be the same test as that with respect to which arrangements had been made for the purpose of cl. 485.215(c).

Indeed, where an application is lodged online, where the application questionnaire specifically does not ask a specific question of an applicant, as in this case, it would be essential that the evidence be submitted subsequent to the formal submission of the online application. We note that the legislative intent as expressed in the explanatory statement accompanying the regulation was to allow applicants additional time to submit the IELTS results provided that they have made arrangements to undertake the English test, just as applicants have additional time to provide the skills assessment, character and medical check results. We also note that the Full Court decision in Minister for Immigration v Grant (2009) FCA 1059 at para 28 notes that the words referred to above are directed towards an outcome contemplated by clause 485.222, being proof that an applicant has competent English. We have been unable to unearth any precise judicial consideration of the term accompanied in this regulation or comparable Migration Regulations . We note that the previous regulatory regime in relation to the predecessor visa subclass 497 made similar provision, but provided that the requirement was contained in Schedule 1 and was therefore a validity requirement.

At the hearing, the Tribunal noted that the Federal Court had recently considered the meaning of paragraph 485.215(c) in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 ( Grant ). Jagot J held:
46. ... Mr Grant did not satisfy the requirements of cl. 485.215(c) of the Migration Regulations . At the time of the application for the visa, he had not "made arrangements to undergo a language test specified by the Minister in an instrument in writing" within the meaning of that provision. ... Hence, the fact that Mr Grant subsequently provided that he had "competent English" by the taking of a test at a later time (and before the Tribunal made its decision) is insufficient; the first requirement had not been met.

For the reasons set out in the Tribunal's decision 071956137 [2008] MRTA 1109 , the Tribunal is of the view that it is able to consider the results of a test undertaken after the application. This view is supported in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 which confirms both that the test undertaken after the application would meet the requirements in cl. 485.222 and also that it need not be the same test as that with respect to which arrangements had been made for the purpose of cl. 485.215(c).

In MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , Jagot J (sitting as the Full Federal Court) found:
37. ... By this I mean that cll 485. [2]15 and 485.222, read together and in the light of ss 31(3) and 65 of the Migration Act and reg 2.03(1) of the Migration Regulations , disclose that the legislature intended to give an applicant two opportunities to demonstrate competent English. An applicant who had taken a test and obtained the results could demonstrate competent English at the time of the application (cl 485.215(b)). An applicant who had made an arrangement to take a test may demonstrate competent English at the time of decision (cc 485.215(c) and 485.222(b)). ...

On 23 October 2009 the Tribunal received a submission from the applicant's agent in respect of the issue in the review, namely whether for the purposes of cl.485.215 the visa application was accompanied by evidence that the applicant had made arrangements to undergo a specified language test. The submissions highlighted the difference between the paper version of the visa application form (1276), which contained a specific question about whether an applicant had booked for an English language test, and the internet application form, which contained no such question. The applicant's agent submitted that the Tribunal could accept that the relevant time of application requirement was met provided that evidence of the language test arrangements at the required time was submitted during the period of processing the application. The agent referred to the judgements in MIAC v Grant (2009) FCA 1059 , MIAC v Kamal (2009) FCFCA 98, Yilmaz v MIMA (2000) FCA and Thayananthan v MIMA (2001) FCA 831 to support his submissions.

On 25 October 2009 the applicant's representative provided the Tribunal with a copy of an IELTS test report form indicating that the applicant had achieved scores of 7.0 for listening, 6.0 for reading, 6.0 for writing and 6.0 for speaking in a test conducted on 8 October 2009. In Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 Jagot J accepted that cl.485.222 should not be read as referring only to the test which the applicant had made arrangements to undergo at the time of application but rather as permitting an applicant to take multiple language tests in order to achieve the necessary result at time of decision.

For the reasons set out in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , the Tribunal is of the view that it is able to consider the results of a test undertaken after the application and further that the test undertaken after the application would meet the requirements in cl. 485.222 and also that it need not be the same test as that with respect to which arrangements had been made for the purpose of cl. 485.215(c).

The applicant argues that he has competent English and he has provided to the Tribunal the results of an IELTS test he had undertaken on 30 May 2009, in which he achieved the score of at least 6 in each of the four test components. These results have been verified by the Tribunal. For the reasons set out in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , the Tribunal is of the view that it is able to consider the results of a test undertaken after the application and further that the test undertaken after the application would meet the requirements in cl. 485.222 and also that it need not be the same test as that with respect to which arrangements had been made for the purpose of cl. 485.215(c).

The Tribunal has taken into account the findings of the Federal Court in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 where the Court held that the applicant did not satisfy cl.485.215(c) because he had not "made arrangements to undergo" a relevant language test. Rather, he had taken the language test but had not achieved the result of competent English as required by cl.485.215(b). In Grant , the fact that the applicant subsequently proved that he had competent English by taking a test at a later time was insufficient.

The applicant has provided to the Tribunal the results of an IELTS test she undertook on 18 April 2009, in which she achieved a score of at least 6 in each of the four test components. These results have been verified by the Tribunal. On the basis of the Federal Court's finding, in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , that a test undertaken after the application would meet the requirements in cl. 485.222 and also that it need not be the same test as that with respect to which arrangements had been made for the purpose of cl. 485.215(c), the Tribunal is satisfied that the applicant's standard of English is at the level of Competent as required for cl.485.222.

As the application was accompanied by evidence that the applicant has made arrangements to undergo a specified language test, clause 485.222 requires that he has competent English at the time of decision. In MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , Jagot J (sitting as the Full Federal Court) found:
37. ... By this I mean that cll 485. [2]15 and 485.222, read together and in the light of ss 31(3) and 65 of the Migration Act and re 2.03(1) of the Migration Regulations , disclose that the legislature intended to give an applicant two opportunities to demonstrate competent English. An applicant who had taken a test and obtained the results could demonstrate competent English at the time of the application (cl 485.215(b)). An applicant who had made an arrangement to take a test may demonstrate competent English at the time of decision (cc 485.215(c) and 485.222(b)). ...

The applicant has provided to the Tribunal the results of an IELTS test she undertook on 12 September 2009, in which she achieved a score of at least 6 in each of the four test components. These results have been verified by the Tribunal. On the basis of the Federal Court's finding, in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , that a test undertaken after the application would meet the requirements in cl. 485.222 and also that it need not be the same test as that with respect to which arrangements had been made for the purpose of cl. 485.215(c), the Tribunal is satisfied that the applicant's standard of English is at the level of Competent and that she meets the requirements of 485.222.

The applicant has provided to the Tribunal the results of an IELTS test he undertook on 18 April 2009, in which he achieved a score of at least 6 in each of the four test components. These results have been verified by the Tribunal. On the basis of the Federal Court's finding, in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , that a test undertaken after the application would meet the requirements in cl. 485.222 and also that it need not be the same test as that with respect to which arrangements had been made for the purpose of cl. 485.215(c), the Tribunal is satisfied that the applicant's standard of English is at the level of Competent level and that he meets the requirements of 485.222.

In MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , Jagot J (sitting as the Full Federal Court) found:
37. ... By this I mean that cll 485. [2]15 and 485.222, read together and in the light of ss 31(3) and 65 of the Migration Act and reg 2.03(1) of the Migration Regulations , disclose that the legislature intended to give an applicant two opportunities to demonstrate competent English. An applicant who had taken a test and obtained the results could demonstrate competent English at the time of the application (cl 485.215(b)). An applicant who had made an arrangement to take a test may demonstrate competent English at the time of decision (cc 485.215(c) and 485.222(b)). ...

The representative submitted that the Tribunal is not bound by the rules of evidence or legal technicalities and the problems with regard to this application are due to the lack of knowledge by the agent. The representative submitted that the Tribunal has the power to set aside the decision made by the Department. The representative provided to the Tribunal a copy of the Federal Magistrates Court decision in Kamal v Minister for Immigration & Anor [2009] FMCA (20 March 2009) and MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059.

The applicant has provided the results of an IELTS test which he undertook on 20 June 2009 showing the requisite scores to demonstrate competent English. The Tribunal has verified these results and accordingly is satisfied that the applicant achieved a test score of at least 6 in each of the four test components in a test conducted not more than 2 years before the day on which the application was lodged. The Tribunal notes that this test was undertaken after the test for which evidence of arrangements was provided at the time of application. The Tribunal considers that there is nothing in the Schedule 2 time of decision criterion that requires the language test for which the applicant made arrangements to undergo at the time of application to be the same test at which the applicant succeeded in obtaining the required English standard. This view is supported in a recent decision of MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [38] .

For the reasons set out in the Tribunal's decision 071956137 [2008] MRTA 1109 , the Tribunal is of the view that it is able to consider the results of a test undertaken after the application. This view is supported in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 which confirms both that the test undertaken after the application would meet the requirements in cl. 485.222 (and equally, in the Tribunal's view, cl. 487.224) and also that it need not be the same test as that with respect to which arrangements had been made for the purpose of cl.

The applicant has provided the results of an IELTS test which she undertook on 13 June 2009 showing the requisite scores to demonstrate competent English. The Tribunal has verified these results and accordingly is satisfied that the applicant achieved a test score of at least 6 in each of the four test components in a test conducted not more than 2 years before the day on which the application was lodged. The Tribunal notes that this test was undertaken before the test for which evidence of arrangements was provided at the time of application. The Tribunal considers that there is nothing in the Schedule 2 time of decision criterion that requires the language test for which the applicant made arrangements to undergo at the time of application to be the same test at which the applicant succeeded in obtaining the required English standard. This view is supported in a recent decision of MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [38] .

On 25 May 2009 the applicant's representative provided the Tribunal with a copy of an IELTS test report form indicating that the applicant had achieved scores of 6.0 for listening, 6.0 for reading, 6.0 for writing and 6.0 for speaking in a test conducted on 4 April 2009. In Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 Jagot J accepted that cl.485.222 should not be read as referring only to the test which the applicant had made arrangements to undergo at the time of application but rather as permitting an applicant to take multiple language tests in order to achieve the necessary result at time of decision.

Under cover of a letter dated 17 September 2009 the applicant's representative provided the Tribunal with a copy of an IELTS test report form indicating that the applicant had achieved scores of 7.0 for listening, 6.0 for reading, 6.0 for writing and 6.5 for speaking in a test conducted on 22 August 2009. In Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 Jagot J accepted that cl.485.222 should not be read as referring only to the test which the applicant had made arrangements to undergo at the time of application but rather as permitting an applicant to take multiple language tests in order to achieve the necessary result at time of decision.

The Tribunal is of the view that it is able to consider the results of an IELTS test undertaken after the application. Comments made obiter dicta by Jagot J in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , indicate that a test undertaken after the application would meet the requirements in cl. 485.222, and that it need not be the same test as that with respect to which arrangements had been made for the purpose of cl. 485.215(c).

Under cover of a letter dated 19 September 2009 the applicant's representative provided the Tribunal with a copy of an IELTS test report form indicating that the applicant had achieved scores of 7.0 for listening, 6.0 for reading, 6.0 for writing and 6.5 for speaking in a test conducted on 22 August 2009. In Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 Jagot J accepted that cl.485.222 should not be read as referring only to the test which the applicant had made arrangements to undergo at the time of application but rather as permitting an applicant to take multiple language tests in order to achieve the necessary result at time of decision.

Under cover of a letter dated 3 December 2008 the applicant's representatives provided the Tribunal with a copy of an IELTS test report form indicating that the applicant had achieved scores of 7.5 for listening, 8.0 for reading, 6.0 for writing and 7.0 for speaking in a test conducted on 15 November 2008. In Minister for Immigration and Citizenship v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 Jagot J accepted that cl.485.222 should not be read as referring only to the test which the applicant had made arrangements to undergo at the time of application but rather as permitting an applicant to take multiple language tests in order to achieve the necessary result at time of decision.

The Tribunal also finds that the applicant has achieved a score of at least 6 in each of the 4 test components on an IELTS test conducted not more than 2 years before the date of application. The Department has verified the IELTS test results. The Tribunal notes that the IELTS test was conducted on 7 February 2009 and therefore relates to a different test than that for which the booking referred. The Tribunal has given consideration to the judgement of the Jagot J. in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 and the Tribunal considers that there is nothing in the Schedule 2 criteria which requires that the language test for which the applicant made arrangements to undergo at time of application be the same test in which the applicant succeeds in obtaining the required English standard. Accordingly, the Tribunal finds that the applicant has 'competent English' as defined in 1.15C(a)(i). The Tribunal finds that the first named applicant meets cl.485.222.

Given this evidence, the Tribunal is of the opinion that cl.485.215(c) was introduced to enable applicants who had sought to undertake an IELTS test but were unable to do so due to 'capacity problems', to make arrangement to register for such a test and to undergo the test when they were able to do so. The Tribunal is satisfied that the intention was that the making of arrangements before the application to undergo the test at a date after the application was sufficient to meet the time of application requirement in cl.485.215(c) and that the test could be undertaken at a later date for the purpose of cl.485.222. Therefore, the Tribunal finds that it is able to give consideration to the results of an IELTS test that was, as in the present case, undertaken after the application is made. The case of MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 supports this interpretation. In the case of MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 , Jagot J commented favourably on an interpretation that permits the Tribunal to consider, for the purposes of cl.485.222, the results of a test which is not be the same test as that with respect to which arrangements had been made for the purpose of cl.485.215(c).

For the reasons set out in the Tribunal's decision 071956137 [2008] MRTA 1109 , the Tribunal is of the view that it is able to consider the results of a test undertaken after the application. This view is supported in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 which confirms both that the test undertaken after the application would meet the requirements in cl. 485.222 and also that it need not be the same test as that with respect to which arrangements had been made for the purpose of cl. 485.215(c).

This view is supported in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 which confirms both that the test undertaken after the application would meet the requirements in cl. 485.222 and also that it need not be the same test as that with respect to which arrangements had been made for the purpose of cl. 485.215(c).

For the reasons set out in the Tribunal's decision 071956137 [2008] MRTA 1109 , the Tribunal is of the view that it is able to consider the results of a test undertaken after the application This view is supported in MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 which confirms both that the test undertaken after the application would meet the requirements in cl. 485.222 and also that it need not be the same test as that with respect to which arrangements had been made for the purpose of cl. 485.215(c).

The wording of the requirement --- that a test must be conducted not more than 2 years before the day on which the application was lodged --- is clear and unambiguous and requires the test to have been conducted within a specified period before the application is made. The past tense in the reference to the test being conducted, at the time of application, also implies that the test must have been conducted before the application was made and not after the date of the application. This is also consistent with the Explanatory Statement in the SLI 2007 No. 257 which relevantly states that r. 1.15C requires the IELTS test to be conducted within the two years before the date of the application. The Tribunal considers the reasoning in Kamal to be unhelpful, as the Full Court considered the statutory provision that was substantially different to the one that is relevant in this case (cf MIAC v Grant [2009] FCA 1059 at [43] ).
